journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Emotional and Behavioral Disorders

title-group.article-title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Standardized Behavior Management Intervention for Students With Externalizing Behavior

author-notes.corresp: Martin Forster, Uppsala University, Department of Psychology, Box 1225, 751 42, Uppsala, Sweden; e-mail: martin@forster.se.

abstract.p: This study reports the results from a Swedish randomized controlled trial of a standardized behavior management intervention. The intervention targeted students with externalizing behavior in a regular education setting. First- and second-grade students (N = 100) from 38 schools were randomly assigned to either the intervention or an active comparison group. Observer, teacher, and peer ratings were collected at pretest, posttest (6 months later), and follow-up (14 months after pretest). Significant intervention effects were found on student externalizing behavior and teacher behavior management at both posttest and follow-up. The intervention effect on student externalizing behavior was mediated by change in teacher behavior. Moderating effects of demographic and classroom variables were explored, as well as the social validity of the intervention. The results are discussed in relation to cost-effectiveness and feasibility of behavioral interventions in typical school settings.

body.p: Externalizing behavior among young children, such as aggressive and disruptive acts, is one of the most important risk factors for a deviant development through adolescence and adulthood (Farrington, 1998; Flanagan, Bierman, & Kam, 2003). The reported prevalence of problem behaviors among students in Sweden is lower compared to other developed countries, but still, approximately 5% of the students are in need of special service and intervention due to serious emotional and behavioral problems (Heiervang, Goodman, & Goodman, 2008). These children enter the school system unprepared for the experience of schooling and often bring emerging antisocial behavior patterns with them (Loeber & Farrington, 1998). Once in the school system, a number of dynamic processes further increase the risk for academic failure and long-term negative outcomes. For example, high-risk students are often subject to an excess of teacher reprimands at the expense of contingent praise (Beaman & Wheldall, 2000; Clunies-Ross, Little, & Kienhuis, 2008; Rydell & Henricsson, 2004; Van Acker, Grant, & Henry, 1996). Furthermore, the level of teacher support and teacher–student conflict have a significant effect on future school and peer adjustment, independent from student behaviors and characteristics (Hamre & Pianta, 2001; Hughes, Lou, Kwok, & Loyd, 2008; Silver, Measelle, Armstrong, & Essex, 2005). Early failure within the school system increases the likelihood of subsequent placement in alternative educational settings and school absenteeism, which is a key risk factor for several serious outcomes including school dropout, suicide attempt, teenage pregnancy, violence, and substance use (Kearney, 2008).

In the United States, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (2004) directly references the need for and use of positive behavioral interventions and functional behavioral assessment processes for students who display problem behavior that impedes their success at school. To meet these requirements, several researchers have developed school-wide intervention models with system-level support for involved school personnel. These models enhance the capacity of schools to design effective environments that improve the fit or link between research-validated practices (e.g., behavior management strategies) and the environments in which teaching and learning occur. An example is School-Wide Positive Behavioral Support (SWPBS; Sugai et al., 2000), which is currently being adopted by more than 7,000 schools across the United States (Bradley, Doolittle, Lopez, Smith, & Sugai, 2007). SWPBS is organized as a three-tiered model, in which the primary tier represents school-wide systems intended to prevent challenging behaviors and affect approximately 85% to 90% of a school’s population. The secondary tier is reserved for students who display emerging or modest challenging behaviors, involving between 7% and 10% of a school population. The tertiary tier targets approximately 3% to 5% of the student body, who require more complex and individualized support beyond their exposure to universal and selective interventions. Interventions at this level are based on functional behavioral assessment (FBA) and involve high investments (e.g., external consultants) to prevent the emergence or continuation of higher intensity problem behaviors. The FBA guides the implementation of behavioral support plans that often include behavior management strategies (BM).

Despite the common use of FBA and BM for individual high-risk students, there are several issues that limit claims about efficacy and effectiveness of such interventions. First, a review of the FBA literature reveals a body of research that spans the past 30 years, but most of the research concerns children in contained settings with serious disabilities and has little direct relation to general education students in classroom settings (Conroy, Clark, Fox, & Gable, 2000; Scott et al., 2004).

Second, the limited evidence supporting FBA and BM in general education settings is primarily based on single- subject and within-group experimental studies (Iovannone et al., 2009; Simonsen, Fairbanks, Briesch, Myers, & Sugai, 2008). There have been promising reports in recent years from randomized trials of school-wide multi-component intervention models involving FBA and BM, such as SWPBS (e.g., Horner et al., 2009; Sorlie & Ogden, 2007). Nevertheless, it is difficult to disentangle the effects of FBA and BM for high-risk students in those studies. In the few randomized trials investigating the specific effect of individual BM, the results have been mixed. Metropolitan Area Child Study Research Group (2002) reported no significant intervention effects on student behavior, whereas Iovannone et al. (2009) found significant effects on student behaviors with effect sizes in the medium range. The present lack of randomized trials of BM, and discrepant views on what counts as credible evidence, has led to conflicting conclusions in reviews of interventions for externalizing behavior. Some reviews state that school-based BM is an evidence-based intervention (e.g., Pelham & Fabiano, 2008; Wilson & Lipsey, 2007), whereas others exclude this type of intervention due to lack of randomized trials (e.g., Eyberg, Nelson, & Boggs, 2008; Mytton, DiGuiseppi, Gough, Taylor, & Logan, 2006). One could argue that evidence from studies using single-subject design shows that individual BM causes behavior change in students, but many researchers would argue that evidence from randomized trials also is necessary to enable high-quality, wide-scale dissemination of such interventions (e.g., American Psychological Association, 2006; Flay & Collins, 2005).

Third, recent evidence suggests that FBA and BM targeting individual students are conducted either with such lack of rigor and logic as to be worthless or with such complexity and formality as to be unrealistic for the typical school setting (Blood & Neel, 2007; Scott, Anderson, & Spaulding, 2008; Van Acker, Boreson, Gable, & Potterton, 2005). To improve the quality of the implementation and increase the feasibility for typical school personnel in everyday school settings, there is a need to develop standardized training models of BM. Such models also provide opportunities to conduct randomized controlled trials with better control of the independent variable (i.e., the intervention).

Fourth, interventions in outcome studies of BM have often been applied with heavy involvement by the researchers (Lane, Weisenbach, Phillips, & Wehby, 2007; Sasso, Conroy, Peck-Stichter, & Fox, 2001). Interventions that largely are implemented by consultants are not realistic options for most school districts, because of the involved costs and lack of qualified specialists. For a fact, most students in need of intervention do not gain access to service at all (Kazdin, 2008).

To conclude, a widespread dissemination of FBA and BM requires the development of intervention models that are not only effective but also feasible and involve limited costs (Romeo, Byford, & Knapp, 2005).

The purpose of this study was to evaluate a standardized FBA-guided behavior management intervention program in a randomized controlled trial. The program targeted individual students, screened for externalizing behavior. The primary outcome domains were measures of student externalizing behavior and teacher behavior management. The lack of active control groups (i.e., attention control or alternative intervention) is a common limitation in school-based intervention research (Flay & Collins, 2005). For that reason, the BM condition was compared with a condition in which the teachers were trained in a universal social and emotional skills training program. The program in the comparison group did not involve training in BM, nor did it directly target externalizing behavior. Our hypothesis was therefore that the BM intervention would outperform the comparison group on measures of student externalizing behavior and teacher behavior management. It was also hypothesized that change in teacher behavior would mediate the change in student externalizing behavior.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Elementary public schools in the greater Stockholm, Sweden, urban area (population = 1.9 million) were informed about the study through announcements. To be included in the study, the teachers had to teach a class in a regular education setting and have at least one student with externalizing behavior problems. The level of externalizing behavior problems was assessed through a screening procedure, in which all students in each teacher’s class were rated on a 5-point rating scale (1 = not at all, 5 = very much). The ratings were then used as a base for discussion between the researchers and the teachers to identify students who were suitable for the study. A written consent from the targeted student’s parent was required for participation. After randomization, the teachers also completed the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (Goodman, 1999). The scale has been shown to discriminate clinical populations of children with diagnoses such as oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) from normal controls (Goodman, 2001; Heiervang et al., 2008; Malmberg, Rydell, & Smedje, 2003). The mean externalizing score for the students included in this study was more than two standard deviations above the average in Scandinavian normative samples (Heiervang et al., 2008). No student scored less than one standard deviation above the normative average.

Of the 100 students included in the study, 86% were boys. The students attended first- and second-grade regular education classrooms (Mage = 8.4 years, SD = 0.6), with an average class size of 22 students (SD = 4.0). In almost one third (29%) of the students’ families, both parents were born abroad, arriving as immigrants primarily from former Yugoslavia, the Middle East, and Northern Africa. This proportion was slightly larger than the average of 20% within the city of Stockholm (Statistics Sweden, 2008). To allocate financial needs to school districts, the City of Stockholm uses a socioeconomic index ranging from 44 to 159 (M = 100, SD = 48). The index is based on factors such as household income, citizenship, marital status, crime rate, employment status, and number of students who drop out of school. Low indexes reflect less poverty and social problems. The participating students attended schools in neighborhoods with an index ranging from 46 to 144 (M = 94, SD = 28), suggesting that the sample was representative of the city population in terms of social and economic factors. A minor part of the targeted students (25%) received between 1 and 3 hours of weekly special education in small groups, besides their regular education. There were no significant differences between the two experimental conditions on any demographic or school-related variables (p > .05).

Because most studies of behavioral school-based interventions have been conducted in the United States, it may be relevant for the reading of this article to state some similarities and differences between the American and Swedish school systems. The Swedish and American educational systems are fairly similar in terms of expenditure on primary and lower secondary educational institutions (Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, 2009). However, all schools in Sweden are publicly funded and parents are free to choose whichever school they wish for their child. The students usually stay in the same classroom with the same teacher over periods of 3 years, in contrast to students in the United States, who usually change teachers each year. Thus, the Swedish system offers opportunities to conduct studies using prolonged training and follow-up assessments with the same teachers.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: A total of 189 teachers from 54 schools indicated their interest to participate in the study. At the time of randomization, 38 teachers did not have a student who met the inclusion criteria and 51 teachers no longer expressed interest in participation. Thus, 100 eligible teacher–student pairs from 38 schools were randomly assigned to either the BM intervention or the comparison group. To prevent spillover effects between conditions, teachers and students from the same schools were grouped and randomized to either intervention or comparison. Thus, the unit of randomization was schools (N = 38), whereas the unit of intervention and measurement was teachers/students (N = 100). Because there were more training resources available for the BM intervention than for the program offered to the comparison group, the intervention group was oversampled. Therefore, 26 schools with 60 teachers/students from 54 classrooms were allocated to the intervention group, whereas 12 schools with 40 teachers/students from 34 classrooms were allocated to the comparison group. Because some teachers shared classrooms, the number of teacher–student pairs was larger than the number of classrooms. In such cases, each teacher was responsible for one targeted student in the class.

Measures were collected at pretest, posttest (6 months after pretest; SD = 1.1 months), and follow-up (14 months after pretest; SD = 0.9 months). Although the measurement timing varied between participants, there were no significant differences between the two groups (p > .05). The same teacher performed the screening, training, and ratings throughout the whole 14-month period, which was possible since teachers in Sweden generally stay with the same group of students for 3 years.

sec.title: The intervention
sec.p: The teacher training procedure in the intervention group followed a program known as “COMET” (Forster & Karlberg, 2005). The program primarily involves FBA-guided interventions targeting individual students but also includes general classroom behavior management strategies. Individually tailored interventions guided by FBA usually are implemented as part of the third tier in school-wide interventions based on the tier model (Horner et al., 2009). However, due to the standardized nature of the COMET program and the fact that a relatively large number of teachers can be served by each consultant, it can probably be applied at both the secondary and tertiary levels within school-wide intervention programs. A detailed program manual supports the standardization of COMET. The program manual includes BM strategies and prescribes homework exercises that are implemented between training workshops. The selection of BM strategies is based on previously published school-intervention manuals and books (e.g., Kratochwill & Bergan, 1990; Morris, 1985; Wielkiewicz, 1995). The manual also includes a simplified stepwise FBA procedure that guides the application of the individual interventions. The first step is to identify problem behaviors and matching behavioral goals for the targeted student. Thereafter, occurrence and triggering antecedents are assessed for 2 weeks, before an individual intervention plan is formulated. All intervention plans include goal setting (i.e., clearly stating the behavioral expectations with the student) and contingent praise when the student engages in the stated behaviors. All interventions also include planned ignoring and positively stated commands in response to problem behaviors, since harsh and negative reprimands often function both as antecedents to and as reinforcement of such behaviors. Thus, the primary targets of change on behalf of the teachers are to increase the use of praise and decrease the use of harsh reprimands. As an option, the teachers can enhance the reinforcement of the goal behaviors through token systems, which in turn could be enhanced through the use of back-up reinforcement by the student’s parents. Once the strategies targeting the individual student are in place, the teachers continue with two BM procedures targeting the entire classroom: stating and reinforcing classroom rules, and cooperative learning exercises. In the latter strategy, the teachers let the students work in pairs with structured academic assignments. The students are instructed to prompt and reinforce each other throughout the exercise.

The content of the program is implemented during nine 3-hour workshops by a consultant with groups of 4 to 5 teachers. The program manual includes detailed agendas prescribing specific activities that are to be covered during each workshop. Behavior management strategies are practiced through modeling and role-playing supported by instructional videotapes. A large part of the workshops is devoted to homework assignment and follow-up. All teachers receive similar assignments, but they are tailored to the individual students through the FBA process. The teachers implement the homework assignments during 1 or 2 weeks between the workshops.

In this study, the first workshop was scheduled directly after pretest measures were collected, and the last workshop was given approximately a month before posttest. During the last workshop, a plan for the maintenance of improvements in behavior management is formulated for each teacher. The teachers in the study attended on average 7.2 (SD = 1.3) of the nine workshops, which means that the average number of total training hours per teacher was 22. The teachers were provided professional development release time to attend the workshops.

For the majority of the workshops (65%), the consultant was a clinical psychologist who was trained in BM and FBA by a professor of special education. A certified teacher and PhD student in education participated as an assistant consultant and subsequently was the leader of a lesser part of the workshops (35%), under supervision of the first consultant. Both workshop consultants were part of the research team.

sec.title: The comparison group
sec.p: The teachers in the comparison group were trained in a universal prevention program known as CHARLIE (Chemical Abuse Resolution Lies In Education), which was developed by the Storefront Group in Minnesota (Project CHARLIE manual, 1987). The program is based on a manual containing 74 lesson plans with social and emotional learning exercises. The classroom teacher implements the program in groups of 15 to 25 students. A specific skill is discussed, modeled, and role-played during one lesson each week. Examples of skills are giving compliments, receiving criticism, listening, conflict resolution, sharing, decision making, assertiveness, and being friendly. The program does not directly target individual students or externalizing behavior, nor does it involve teacher behavior management. Thus, the program was not expected to have a specific effect on measures related to student externalizing behaviors or teacher behavior management. Instead, the purpose was to provide credible attention to the comparison group teachers, as opposed to using a wait-list or no-treatment control group. The reason for choosing CHARLIE was that it is a highly accepted and widespread school-based program in Sweden, despite the lack of supporting research evidence (Ferrer-Wreder, Stattin, Lorente, Tubman, & Adamson, 2004).

Certified staff from the CHARLIE organization in Sweden trained groups of 20 teachers during two full-day workshops, which mainly were devoted to role-playing of lesson plans from the manual. The workshops were scheduled immediately after the pretest measurement collection. After the workshops, the teachers applied the program without further support or guidance, consistent with the manner in which the program is typically implemented. The teachers were provided professional development release time to attend the workshops. Because the study targeted individual high-risk students, the teachers were given the rationale that these students might benefit as a result of general improvement of social and emotional skills in the entire class. To further increase the credibility of the intervention in the comparison group, the teachers were offered to take part in an additional 3-hour small group workshop. During the workshop, the participants discussed the parts of the CHARLIE program that would be most beneficial for the targeted high-risk students. Three of the teachers in the comparison group missed one of the full-day workshops and six teachers missed the 3-hour workshop. Thus, on average, the teachers attended 18 training hours in the comparison group.

sec.title: Intervention fidelity
sec.p: The primary targets of change on behalf of the teachers in the intervention group, increased use of praise at the expense of harsh reprimands, were measured through independent observations and are reported in the Results section. The fidelity of other intervention strategies in the BM program was measured through teacher reports at posttest and follow-up. Because the interventions were tailored to the individual students’ needs, the specific strategies that the teachers implemented varied. All teachers (100%) stated behavioral goals for the targeted students and reported that they subsequently praised those behaviors. Most teachers also applied a token system linked to the behavioral goals (73% and 75% at posttest and follow-up, respectively). Slightly less than half of the teachers included home notes with back-up reinforcement as part of the token system (45% at both measurement points). It was also assessed to what extent the teachers implemented the general classroom management strategies. Most teachers stated and reinforced classroom rules (68% and 73% at posttest and follow-up, respectively). Cooperative learning exercises were implemented by less than half of the teachers (38% and 48% at posttest and follow-up, respectively), who used the exercises during 15 lessons on average (SD = 15).

Because the purpose of the program in the comparison group was to provide the teachers with credible attention, no fidelity measures related to the content of that program were collected. However, the teachers reported the number of implemented training lessons, which on average was 13 (SD = 11) at posttest and 19 (SD = 19) at follow-up.

During the time period between pretest and follow-up, the teachers in both conditions were instructed not to use any materials or strategies from the other condition. This was in part controlled for through the randomization process, in which all teachers from a single school were allocated to the same condition.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The students were the main targets in the study, but measures of teacher behavior were also collected, because FBA and BM are based on the idea that student behavior change is facilitated through change in teacher behavior. Thus, the main outcome domains were externalizing student behavior, teacher praise, and teacher reprimands. Because externalizing behavior often coincides and interacts with hyperactivity and peer problems (Ladd, 2006; Pedersen, Vitaro, Barker, & Borge, 2007; Rudolph & Asher, 2000; Snyder, Prichard, Schrepferman, Patrick, & Stoolmiller, 2004), secondary measures related to these constructs were also collected. Finally, student on-task behavior during deskwork was measured, due to the increased risk of academic failure for students with externalizing behavior (Kearney, 2008). The specific measures that were collected within each construct are specified below.

sec.title: Independent observations
sec.p: At each measurement point, independent observers who were kept blind to the experimental condition visited the classroom of the targeted students for one full day. This means that every participating teacher–student pair was observed for 4 to 5 hours on three occasions (pretest, posttest, and follow-up). The students had the same schedule on each occasion, which included at least one lesson of individual deskwork. Three types of recordings were performed.

First, the observers used continuous event recordings of the targeted student’s externalizing behavior as well as harsh teacher reprimands directed at those students. These recordings were extended throughout the entire day and included recess. Externalizing behavior was defined as a student acting in ways that disturbed or hurt other students and/or the teacher (e.g., teasing, making noise, or acting aggressively). A harsh reprimand was defined as raising the voice and/or using negative descriptions of the students’ behavior.

Second, the time on task of the targeted student was recorded through time sampling during 40 minutes of deskwork. Every 30 seconds, the observer recorded whether or not the student was on task, which was defined as actively engaging in the task at hand or listening to the teacher.

Third, after the deskwork observation period and at the end of the observation day, the observer made an estimate of how many times the target student was explicitly praised by the teacher on a 3-point scale (0 = never, 1 = one or two times, 2 = three or more times). The cutoff at three or more instances of praise generated an even distribution of the data. The two estimates of praise (after deskwork and at the end of the day) were correlated in the moderate to strong range at pretest, posttest, and follow-up (r = .57, r = .50, and r = .70, respectively). Therefore, a composite praise score was computed as the standardized mean of the two scores. The reason for not using a continuous event recording of teacher praise was that it was expected to occur with low frequency.

The observers were master’s students in psychology who were recruited for the purpose of the study. Although the observers were kept blind to the intervention condition, it may sometimes have been obvious that the teachers they visited participated in a particular experimental condition. Therefore, to prevent bias, the observers were also kept uninformed of the specific content of the teacher training in the two conditions, as well as the purpose of the study. As far as possible, the same observer visited a teacher at pretest, posttest, and follow-up, which was achieved in about half of the cases. Before pretest, members of the research team trained the observers to criterion by showing videotapes of teacher–student interactions. The interrater reliability was good to excellent between the trained observers (.67 < K < .84). For the purpose of validating the observer ratings, the teachers completed a brief rating at the end of the day during which the observer visited the classroom. The teachers were kept blind to the ratings performed by the observer, and vice versa. The rating consisted of three items that were conceptually matched with the observer-rated behaviors. Each item was rated from 1 (never/very bad) to 5 (all of the time/very good). The first item (“How often did the student act disturbingly in the classroom?”) was significantly correlated with the observer rating of student externalizing behavior across all measurement points (r = .40, r = .43, and r = .52, respectively). The second item (“How much of the time was the student engaged in schoolwork?”) was in turn consistently correlated with the observer rating of time on task (r = .52, r = .60, and r = .41, respectively). The third item (“How was your relation to the child during the day?”) was expected to correlate with the observer rating of teacher reprimands and praise. However, only the observer rating of teacher reprimands was consistently correlated with that item (r = −.38, r = −.39, and r = −.30, respectively). For teacher praise, the correlation was only significant at pretest (r = .27). Nevertheless, for the most part, the daily teacher ratings supported the validity of the independent observations.

The distributions of the observer ratings of student externalizing behavior and teacher reprimands were skewed. Therefore, those variables were transformed using modular ranks before further analyses were conducted (Zimmerman, 1992, in press). The variance homogeneity of the nontransformed variables was tested with Levene’s test, since heterogeneity has been found to inflate the risk of Type I error in rank transformations (Zimmerman, 2004). The test revealed that the variance was equal in the experimental conditions.

sec.title: Teacher ratings
sec.p: The teacher rating used in the study was the Conners Teacher Rating Scale (CTRS-39; Conners, 1990; DuPaul, Power, McGoey, Ikeda, & Anastopoulos, 1998). Each item in the CTRS is rated between 0 (not at all) and 3 (very much). The internal consistencies in the present sample of the CTRS subscales were α = .77 for externalizing behavior (conduct problems), α = .76 for hyperactivity, and α = .72 for peer problems (asocial).

The teachers also performed a brief class-wide rating of externalizing behavior (BREB) for the targeted students and his or her classmates (N = 1,940 for all students in the targeted students classrooms). A reason for including this measure was that it allows for normative comparisons. The scale has been used by the research group in previous studies (e.g., Sundell, 2000; Sundell & Kraft, 2002) and consists of three items rated between 1 (almost never) and 5 (almost always), which are averaged to achieve a total score for each student. The items are “aggressive—starts fights, is mean to peers, hits or pushes other students,” “disruptive—disrupts play or activities,” and “peer aggression—is intrusive and seeks contact in aggressive ways.” The test–retest reliability of the instrument has been shown to be adequate (r = .72; Sundell, 2000). The internal consistency of the scale was α = .82 in the present study. The scale has been shown to correlate with peer ratings (r = .41; Sundell, 2000) and the predictive validity of the scale was tested in a 3-year longitudinal study of the effect of externalizing behavior and other risk factors on alcohol use. In that study, a BREB rating of 811 students in Grade 3 was the strongest predictor (r = .42) of alcohol use in Grade 6 (Sundell & Kraft, 2002). The mean of the scale for all of the students (N = 1,940) in the present sample was 1.8 (SD = 0.9), 1.7 (SD = 0.8), and 1.7 (SD = 0.8) at pretest, posttest, and follow-up, respectively.

sec.title: Peer ratings
sec.p: Positive and negative peer nominations were collected in each class by a research assistant, following the procedures described by Coie, Dodge, and Coppotelli (1982). The names of all students in a given class were handed out to the participants. The research assistant who administered the peer ratings ensured that the students recognized the names of all classmates by reading them aloud in front of the class. The children were then asked to circle the names of the three children they most liked to play with (positive nominations) and the three children they least liked to play with (negative nominations). The nominations were standardized within classrooms.

Peer nominations have been shown to be reliable and valid with both younger and older children (Ladd, Herald, & Andrews, 2006). They correlate with observed behavior (Newcomb, Bukowski, & Pattee, 1993) as well as later behavior problems (e.g., Ladd, 2006; Parker & Asher, 1987). For the targeted students and their classmates (N = 1,940), the correlation between the positive and negative nominations was r = −.31. Test–retest reliability across 6 months was investigated in a separate untreated sample (N = 817) and was r = .72 and r = .55 for negative and positive nominations, respectively (Forster, 2010). The negative nominations variable was correlated with teacher-rated externalizing behavior (BREB) at pretest (r = .48), which was stronger compared to the corresponding correlation for the positive nominations variable (r = −.19). Relatively stronger links between negative nominations and externalizing behavior have also been reported in previous studies (Johnston, Pelham, Crawford, & Atkins, 1988; Pope, Mumma, & Bierman, 1991). Due to the different implications of positive and negative nominations, the variables were reported separately, instead of the commonly used procedure in which the negative nominations are subtracted from the positive (Coie et al., 1982).

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: At baseline, the experimental conditions were compared using a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) for the outcome measures and demographic variables that were measured with continuous variables. For the categorical demographic variables (e.g., gender), chi-square was used in the comparison. Intervention effects were analyzed separately at posttest and follow-up, using a repeated measures ANOVA. The independent variables were Experimental Condition (intervention vs. comparison) and Time (pre–post and pre–follow-up, respectively).

The participating targeted students (N = 100) were nested within classrooms (N = 88), which were nested within schools (N = 38). To control for dependence among participants, the most conservative measure would have been to conduct the analyses of intervention effects at the school level (N = 38), which was the unit of randomization. However, that would not give a fair representation of the effects, because the unit of intervention was at the student level (N = 100). Therefore, to account for the nesting of participants, the following measures were taken. First, an analysis was conducted that compared the intervention effects at the class level (N = 88) with the effects at the student level (N = 100), which revealed no differences. Therefore, to account for the nesting of students within classrooms, all analyses of the outcome measures were conducted at the class level (N = 88). Second, to account for the nesting of classrooms within schools, the intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) and variation inflation factors (VIFs) were calculated for every outcome measure (Murray & Hannan, 1990). The ICC represents the extent to which an outcome measure correlates between classes within the same school. The VIFs are derived from the ICCs and are used to compensate the F values in the analyses of intervention effects. The mean ICC for the outcome measures was 0.09 (SD = 0.10). ICCs at that level are considered to be high, which means that the classrooms within the schools were fairly dependent. Nevertheless, the mean VIF was only 1.13 (SD = 0.14), which is low considering that a VIF of 1.0 indicates no dependence among classrooms. The reason for the low VIF values was that most schools contained only one or two participating classes. To summarize, the analyses of the intervention effects were performed at the classroom level (N = 88), accounting for the nesting of students within classrooms. The F values in the ANOVAs were then adjusted with the VIFs, which accounted for the nesting of classrooms within schools (Murray, 1998).

With an alpha set at .05 and a sample size of 88 classrooms, the statistical power to detect a small to medium effect size (d = .35) was .80 (Critical F = 3.95). The statistical power was calculated using computer software G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).

sec.title: Attrition and Missing Data
sec.p: Three participating student–teacher pairs had dropped out at posttest, of which two were from the intervention group and one was from the comparison group. At follow-up, a total of 14 participants had dropped out, 8 from the intervention group and 6 from the comparison group. The reasons for dropout were that 6 teachers had left the schools, 5 teachers reported that their targeted students had transferred to other schools, and 3 teachers had dropped out for unknown reasons. With respect to those participants who completed the entire study, the amount of missing data was approximately 6% per participant across the pre, post, and follow-up measurement points. Consistent with recent literature in addressing missing data and attrition, a multiple imputation procedure was used (Brown et al., 2008; Little & Rubin, 2002; Schafer & Graham, 2002). This allows for an intention-to-treat analysis, since all participants in the study can be included in the analysis. Five imputed data sets were created using the software NORM v.2.03 (Schafer, 1999) with pretest measures as covariates. The imputation was performed separately for each group to preserve treatment effects.

A supplementary analysis of the intervention effects with nonimputed data was also performed (i.e., completers of the study). There were no differences between the results in that analysis and the results in the intention-to-treat analysis, which are presented in Table 2.

sec.title: Baseline Comparisons
sec.p: There were no significant differences between the two experimental conditions in terms of student gender, age, immigrant status, special education status, class size, or socioeconomic level of the schools (p > .10). Furthermore, the groups were equal in terms of outcome measures at pretest (p > .05), apart from the CTRS hyperactivity scale, F(1, 86) = 5.7, p < .05. Means and standard deviations for all measurement points are presented in Table 1.

caption.p: Means and Standard Deviations for Outcome Measures at Pretest, Posttest, and Follow-Up

fn.p: Note: BM = behavior management strategies; CTRS = Conners Teacher Rating Scale; BREB = Brief Rating of Externalizing Behavior.

sec.title: Analyses of Primary Outcome Measures
sec.p: At posttest, there were significant interaction effects (Time × Group) for observed student externalizing behavior and observed teacher reprimands (see Table 2). For these measures, the students and teachers in the BM group showed a more favorable development across time than the comparison group. The effect sizes (d) were in the medium range. At follow-up, four out of five primary outcome measures showed significant interaction effects in favor of the intervention group (Table 2). The effect sizes for the student measures were in the medium range, whereas the teacher measures showed large effects. There was a main effect of time for the CTRS subscale of externalizing behavior and the BREB teacher rating. An inspection of the mean values across time (Table 1) suggests that teachers in both groups experienced improvements across time on the CTRS scale, whereas the main effect for the BREB was due to the improvements in the intervention group alone.

caption.p: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Repeated Measures for Primary and Secondary Outcome Measures at Posttest and Follow-Up

fn.p: Note: CTRS = Conners Teacher Rating Scale; BREB = Brief Rating of Externalizing Behavior.

fn.label: a.
fn.p: In a supplementary analysis, controlling for the pretest difference and the pretest-intervention interaction (Norman & Streiner, 2008), a significant intervention effect was found at follow-up, F(2, 84) = 5.66, p < .01.

sec.p: An analysis of mediation was conducted to explore the hypothesis that change in teacher behavior would cause change in student externalizing behavior. First, a composite measure of change in student externalizing behavior at follow-up was computed as the mean of the standardized values of the three related outcome measures (observed student externalizing behavior, BREB, and the CTRS subscale of externalizing behavior). Second, an analysis of mediation was performed using several regression analyses, following the recommendations by Baron and Kenny (1986). There was a significant effect of experimental condition on student externalizing behavior change, β = .32, t(88) = 2.88, p < .01. There was also a significant effect of experimental condition on the mediator variable (teacher reprimands), β = .29, t(88) = 2.72, p < .01. When controlling for the effect of experimental condition, β = .25, t(88) = 2.36, p < .05, the effect of teacher reprimands on student externalizing behavior was also significant, β = .36, t(88) = 3.33, p < .01. The fact that the direct effect between experimental condition on student externalizing behavior (β = .25) was lower than the total effect (β = .32) implies that change in teacher reprimands partially mediated the intervention effects on student externalizing behavior. The mediation was significant according to the Sobel test, z(88) = 2.1, p < .05 (Baron & Kenny, 1986). The lack of a significant intervention effect on teacher praise at posttest prevented an analysis of the mediating role of praise.

sec.title: Analyses of Secondary Outcome Measures
sec.p: Among the secondary outcome measures, significant interaction effects (Time × Group) were found for positive peer nominations at both posttest and follow-up (Table 2). The effect sizes were in the medium range favoring the intervention group. Furthermore, a significant interaction effect between time and group was found at follow-up for the CTRS hyperactivity scale when controlling for the difference in pretest scores and the pretest–intervention interaction, according to procedures suggested by Norman and Streiner (2008). The students in the intervention group showed larger reductions in hyperactivity across time than the comparison group and the effect size was in the medium range.

sec.title: Moderators of Intervention Effects
sec.p: Multiple regression analyses with forced entry were conducted to examine the possible moderating effects of student age, gender, immigrant status, special education status, class size, and the socioeconomic index of the student’s school. For each regression analysis, the pretest score of the outcome variable, a dummy variable that represented the intervention group, and the tested moderator variable were entered into the first equation. In the second equation, the interaction between intervention condition and the moderator variable was added. With a strong moderator effect, the addition of the interaction variable increases the accounted variance. Only two instances moderated the intervention effect—socioeconomic index for the outcome variable of teacher praise at posttest, and special education status on the outcome of time on task at follow-up. Two significant moderator variables are less than what would have been expected by chance, given 120 analyses (6 moderator variables × 10 outcome variables × 2 measurement points) and p < .05, which suggests that the intervention effects were unaffected by the moderator variables.

sec.title: Acceptability of the interventions
sec.p: A questionnaire was administered at posttest to assess how acceptable and credible the teachers found the interventions in the two experimental conditions. The questionnaire contained seven items that were rated from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much) with an internal consistency of α = .98 (e.g., “To what extent will you continue to use the intervention after the study?”; “How easy was the intervention to implement in your classroom?”; and “How confident would you be in recommending this intervention to a colleague?”). The questionnaire was administered anonymously to prevent the teachers from giving socially desirable answers. The average score was 4.4 for the intervention group (SD = 0.4) as well as for the comparison group (SD = 0.4), which suggests that the teachers in both groups perceived the programs as equally acceptable and credible.

sec.title: Normative comparisons
sec.p: Some measures were collected from the targeted students as well as their classmates (N = 1,940), which offered opportunities for normative comparisons. At follow-up, the targeted students in the intervention group had gained almost one positive peer nomination on average, resulting in the same number of positive nominations as their classmates (Z = 0.0). In contrast, the number of negative nominations was still almost one standard deviation above the class means for both groups at follow-up. At pretest, 73% and 63% of the targeted students were rated at least one standard deviation above the average student on externalizing behavior (BREB) in the intervention and comparison groups, respectively. At follow-up, this proportion was only 39% in the intervention group, whereas a slight increase was evident in the comparison group (72%). The difference between the groups at follow-up was significant, χ2(2, 100) = 8.7, p < .01.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The hypothesis that the BM intervention group would outperform the comparison group in terms of student externalizing behavior and teacher behavior management was partly supported at posttest and fully supported at follow-up. At posttest, significant intervention effects were found on observer-rated student externalizing behavior as well as teacher reprimands. At follow-up, these results were maintained and further significant effects emerged on the teacher rating of externalizing behavior (BREB) and the observer rating of teacher praise. Due to the significant intervention effect on teacher reprimands at posttest, it was possible to demonstrate that change in teacher reprimands mediated the intervention effect on student externalizing behavior at follow-up. The intervention effects were demonstrated to be socially valid in terms of acceptability ratings and normative comparisons to the targeted students’ classmates. None of the explored demographic or classroom variables moderated the intervention effects. Of the secondary outcome measures, significant intervention effects were found for positive peer nominations at posttest and follow-up and for the teacher rating of hyperactivity at follow-up.

A notable result in this study was the long-term intervention effects. A possible explanation for the delayed effects on some of the outcome measures may be that students stay with the same teachers for several years in Sweden. The teachers had time to learn and master the BM strategies and the students were exposed to them during extended periods. Although follow-up data still are to be reported, Iovannone et al. (2009) suggested in their preliminary report that intervention effects seem to fade. More frequent changes in classrooms and teachers in North America may be related to the lack of long-term effects. The delayed effect on teacher praise was due to a decreased rate of teacher praise across time in the comparison group, rather than an increase of praise in the intervention group. Studies have shown that teachers in general express less praise toward students with externalizing behavior and that the level of praise deteriorates across time (Beaman & Wheldall, 2000). Thus, the intervention seems to have buffered a natural decline in praise, an effect that also was reported in Metropolitan Area Child Study Research Group and Gorman-Smith (2003). Nevertheless, it was disappointing that the teachers in the intervention group failed to increase the absolute level of praise, especially since contingent praise is a core strategy in the intervention program. The reason for this failure is not known, but a possible explanation is that teachers in general have been shown to provide most praise contingent upon student academic responses, rather than prosocial behaviors (Beaman & Wheldall, 2000; Van Acker et al., 1996). Because the intervention program did not directly target academic skills, the failure to increase the level of teacher praise may have been due to lack of setting events (i.e., correct academic responses from students).

The intervention effect on student externalizing behavior was more evident in the observational measure than in teacher ratings. Perhaps the BM intervention changed actual behavior but did not alter the teachers’ perception of the targeted students. A possible explanation is that teacher ratings are less sensitive to the present context, resulting in more susceptibility to expectation effects and other forms of bias (De Los Reyes & Kazdin, 2005). This explanation is supported by the significant intervention effects on the class-wide BREB rating, in contrast to the ratings of individual students (CTRS). When completing the BREB rating, the teachers consider the targeted students’ present behavior in relation to that of his or her classmates. This process may be less susceptible to biases compared to individual ratings, in which teachers only can consider a student’s behavior in relation to their recollection of that student’s earlier behavior.

Unlike teacher praise, change in teacher reprimands correlated with student behaviors and mediated the intervention effects. This is in accord with previous studies that have demonstrated stronger effects of teacher negativity on student externalizing behavior, compared to effects of teacher support (e.g., Clunies-Ross et al., 2008; Hamre & Pianta, 2001; Silver et al., 2005). An explanation to this contrast can be found in the numerous studies of reciprocal interactions by Gerald Patterson and colleagues (Patterson, 1982). They have shown that the function of a certain behavior (e.g., positive interactions) has a different implication than the absolute frequency or strength of that behavior (Granic, O’Hara, Pepler, & Lewis, 2007; Granic & Patterson, 2006). Thus, some behaviors need to be assessed and analyzed in moment-to-moment observations rather than through regression analyses of pre–post scores. Van Acker et al. (1996) applied this theoretical framework in a study of the reciprocal relationship between teacher and behaviors among high-risk students. They found that teacher reprimands were highly contingent upon student externalizing behavior. Teacher praise, on the other hand, was delivered noncontingent upon student prosocial and academic behaviors. Even if the observers in this study coded contingent praise from teachers, the specific reciprocal functions of teacher and student behaviors were not taken into account, as in observations of moment-to-moment interactions (e.g., Granic & Patterson, 2006).

The relative lack of intervention effects on the secondary outcome measures was disappointing, but maybe not surprising, considering the brief nature and limited scope of the intervention. A possible explanation for the differential effect on positive and negative peer nominations is that negative peer appraisals have been shown to be more stable across time (i.e., harder to change) compared to positive appraisals (Johnston et al., 1988). Furthermore, it has been shown that the effect of teacher–student interactions, which were altered in this study, is greater on positive than on negative appraisals from peers (Hughes, Cavell, & Willson, 2001). Although there was a significant intervention effect on teacher-rated hyperactivity, that result has to be interpreted with caution considering the difference between the groups at pretest and that no observational measure was collected for hyperactivity.

Of previous school-based intervention studies, the most relevant comparison to this study probably is Iovannone et al. (2009), in which a similar FBA-based BM intervention was evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. The effect size on student externalizing behavior was d = 0.44 at posttest, which was similar to the findings in this study. A strength of the investigated intervention in Iovannone et al. (2009) was the team-based approach and inclusion of an elaborative fidelity check with continuous control of the implementation procedure. Another strength was that the consultation partly involved direct observation of the teachers in the classroom settings, which generally has been shown to have a greater effect on teacher behavior compared to group consultation (Noell et al., 2005). However, the intervention model used in the present study required less invested time by the teacher consultants. In Iovannone et al. (2009), the time a consultant spent on a case was 12 hours plus five meetings that ranged between 30 minutes and 2 hours. As a consequence, each consultant used between 15 and 22 hours per teacher, compared to about 6 hours per teacher in this study. This issue is of great importance, considering the lack of well-trained consultants and financial resources available for school-based mental health (e.g., Scott et al., 2008). On the other hand, the intervention model in the present study requires 20 to 30 active training hours during a semester for each participating teacher, which may be demanding for regular education teachers. When implementing this type of teacher training intervention the use of school-wide models with systems-level support may therefore be necessary (Sugai & Horner, 2002).

A strength of this study was the use of an active comparison group. Although the attention provided to the teachers in the two conditions was not entirely comparable, it was nevertheless a methodological advantage to use a credible intervention as comparison. This is especially important in relation to teacher ratings, which are more susceptible to bias compared to more objective measures (De Los Reyes & Kazdin, 2005). Another strength of the study was the external validity, which was due to the fact that the participants were recruited from a large number of schools in diverse settings. It could be argued that the validity of the results is limited to the Swedish context. In comparison to the United States, for example, externalizing problems may be less prevalent in the student population and students in Sweden usually stay with the same teachers for longer periods of time. The finding that the intervention effects were more pronounced at follow-up also implies that this type of intervention primarily is applicable in contexts where teachers stay with the same students at least for 2 years. Alternatively, the results point to the possibility that there may be general advantages in terms of teacher–student relationships, and development of student behaviors in school systems where students change teachers less frequently. Nevertheless, the fact that the vast majority of school-based intervention studies have been conducted in North America calls for studies from other cultural contexts.

There were also some limitations of the study, which primarily were related to the observational measures. The interrater reliability was only assessed during the initial training of the observers. Therefore, it is not certain that the reliability of the observations was preserved across measurement points. However, the stable correlations between the daily teacher ratings and the observer ratings support the reliability and validity of the observations. Although the daily teacher ratings generally supported the validity of the observations, there was a troubling lack of support for the observer rating of teacher praise. One reason for this may be that the observers estimated the amount of praise twice daily, unlike teacher reprimands that were coded through continuous event recordings. Estimates of praise were used because the frequency of contingent praise was expected to be low. A second reason may be that teacher praise to high-risk students has been shown to occur with no conditional relation to student behaviors (Van Acker et al., 1996). Another limitation of the study was the number of observation periods at each measurement point. Although the absolute amount of observed time was sufficient on each occasion (4–5 hours), the reliability would have been stronger with shorter observation periods during several days at each measurement point. The reason for choosing to conduct the observations during a single day was mainly logistic and due to lack of funding for observers. There was also a limitation with regard to the teacher ratings of student behaviors. One of the outcome measures (BREB) was a scale developed by the research group. A more widely used and established scale would have been preferred. The reason for choosing BREB was that no suitable published class-wide scale of student externalizing behavior was found when the study was conducted.

In conclusion, there are two major contributions of this study. First, it is one of the few randomized controlled trials of FBA-guided BM. Second, the results support the effectiveness of FBA and BM, when implemented in a standardized fashion with limited involvement of external consultants. With regard to the lack of similar studies, there is a need for further investigations of school-based interventions that can be disseminated with limited involved costs and resources. In line with this, Kazdin (2008) points out that the debate about evidence-based intervention research so far has focused on issues related to efficacy and effectiveness. He states that less often discussed is the more salient issue, namely, that most students in need of interventions do not receive service at all. Thus, this study is an important step in developing intervention models that enable students in need of service to gain access to effective FBA and BM.

fn.p: The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article: Support for this research was provided by the Mentor Foundation in Sweden, The School Board of Stockholm, The Institute for Evidence-Based Social Work Practice within the National Board of Health and Welfare in Sweden (Dnr 01-7247/2000), and The Swedish National Council for Crime Prevention (Dnr B33-0573/2000). The University of Arizona, as well as the David and Minnie Meyerson Foundation’s Endowed Distinguished Professorship of Disability and Rehabilitation at the University of Arizona, has financed the work and travels to Sweden of Richard J. Morris.

bio.title: About the Authors
bio.p: Martin Forster, PhD, has recently received his doctoral degree from Uppsala University, Sweden. He is a licensed clinical psychologist and currently employed at the National Board of Health and Welfare. His interests include evidence-based practices in general and childhood interventions in particular

Knut Sundell, PhD, is an associate professor in the department of psychology, Uppsala University, and senior advisor for social affairs at the National Board of Health and Welfare, Sweden. His present work involves promoting the dissemination of an evidence-based social work practice in Sweden.

Richard J. Morris, PhD, is the David and Minnie Meyerson Distinguished Professor of Disability and Rehabilitation and professor and director of the School Psychology Program, Department of Disability and Psychoeducational Studies, University of Arizona. His research interests currently focus on the relationship between disability and juvenile delinquency, competency to stand trial in juvenile offenders, and the management of aggressive and disruptive behaviors in the classroom.
Martin Karlberg is a doctoral candidate of educational research at Uppsala University. His current interests in- clude classroom management, behavior analysis, truancy, and bullying

Lennart Melin, PhD, is a professor of clinical psychology in the department of psychology at Uppsala University, Sweden. He is a licensed clinical psychologist and is also licensed in psychotherapy. His main interest is learning-based intervention research, especially within the fields of behavior medicine and health psychology. He has also done research on psychiatric disorders, drug abuse, and classroom management and has published more than 100 articles within these fields
